text: (code chunks disabled vignette build throwing errors. TODO: debug re-enable.)
code: require(raster) require(sp) require(ggplot2) require(PEcAn.visualization) data(yielddf, package = "PEcAn.visualization")  #pecan.worldmap(yielddf, outfile=file.path(tempdir(), 'foo.png'))  spdf <- SpatialPointsDataFrame( data.frame( x = testdf$y , y = testdf$x ) , data = data.frame( z = testdf$z ) )  # Plotting the points reveals the unevenly spaced nature of the points spplot(spdf)

title: Maps
code: files <- dir("~/dev/bety/local/modelout", pattern="grid.csv", full.names=TRUE) yieldfiles <- files[!grepl("evapotranspiration", files)] etfiles <- files[grepl("evapotranspiration", files)] for(file in yieldfiles){     df.in <- read.csv(file)      outfile <- gsub("csv", "png", file)          #pecan.worldmap(df.in, outfile=outfile) }   for(file in etfiles){   df.in <- read.csv(file, skip = 1)   outfile <- gsub("csv", "png", file)   #pecan.worldmap(df.in, outfile=outfile) }

title: Maps
code: # Make an evenly spaced raster, the same extent as original data e <- extent( spdf )  # Determine ratio between x and y dimensions ratio <- ( e@xmax - e@xmin ) / ( e@ymax - e@ymin )  # Create template raster to sample to r <- raster( nrows = 56 , ncols = floor( 56 * ratio ) , ext = extent(spdf) ) rf <- rasterize( spdf , r , field = "" z, fun = mean )  # Attributes of our new raster (# cells quite close to original data) rf  # We can then plot this using `geom_tile()` or `geom_raster()` rdf <- data.frame( rasterToPoints( rf ) )     ggplot( NULL ) + geom_raster( data = rdf , aes( x , y , fill = layer ) ) # from http://gis.stackexchange.com/a/20052/3218 require(rgdal) proj4string(spdf) <- CRS("+init=epsg:4326") pts <- spTransform(spdf ,CRS("+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84")) gridded(spdf) <- TRUE  p2g <- points2grid(spdf, tolerance = 0.95)  r <- raster(p2g) plot(p2g)

title: Variable-width (diagonally cut) histogram — dhist
text: constructing histogram, common make bars width. One also choose make area. two options complementary strengths weaknesses; equal-width histogram oversmooths regions high density, poor identifying sharp peaks; equal-area histogram oversmooths regions low density, identify outliers. describe compromise approach avoids defects. regard histogram exploratory device, rather estimate density.

title: Variable-width (diagonally cut) histogram — dhist
code: dhist(   x,   a = 5 * iqr(x),   nbins = grDevices::nclass.Sturges(x),   rx = range(x, na.rm = TRUE),   eps = 0.15,   xlab = "x",   plot = TRUE,   lab.spikes = TRUE )

title: Variable-width (diagonally cut) histogram — dhist
text: x numeric vector (data) scaling factor, default 5 * IQR nbins number bins, default assigned Stuges method rx range used left left-bin right right-bin eps used set artificial bound min width / max height bins described Denby Mallows (2009) page 24 xlab label x axis plot = TRUE produces plot, FALSE returns heights, breaks counts lab.spikes = TRUE labels % data spikes

title: Variable-width (diagonally cut) histogram — dhist
text: list two elements, heights length n breaks length n+1 indicating heights break points histogram bars.

title: Variable-width (diagonally cut) histogram — dhist
text: Lorraine Denby, Colin Mallows. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics. March 1, 2009, 18(1): 21-31. doi:10.1198/jcgs.2009.0002.

what: Load the tower dataset and create a plot. — plot_netcdf
title: Load the tower dataset and create a plot. — plot_netcdf
text: Loads tower data HDF5 file generated ED plot values one another. default given variable plotted time.

title: Load the tower dataset and create a plot. — plot_netcdf
code: plot_netcdf(   datafile,   yvar,   xvar = "time",   width = 800,   height = 600,   filename = NULL,   year = NULL )

title: Load the tower dataset and create a plot. — plot_netcdf
text: datafile specific datafile use. yvar variable plot along y-axis. xvar variable plot along x-axis, default time used. width width image generated, default 800 pixels. height height image generated, default 600 pixels. filename name file name generated, can null use existing device, otherwise try create image based filename, display x11. year year data (used title).

title: Load the tower dataset and create a plot. — plot_netcdf

title: Theme border for plot — theme_border
text: ggplot2 display specified borders, e.g. ('L'-shaped) borders, rather rectangle border. Note order can significant; example, specify L border option theme, theme settings override border option, need specify theme () border option, .

title: Theme border for plot — theme_border
text: Rudolf Cardinal ggplot2 google group

title: Theme border for plot — theme_border
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ df = data.frame( x=c(1,2,3), y=c(4,5,6) ) ggplot(data=df, aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point() + theme_bw() +        opts(panel.border = theme_border(c('bottom','left')) ) ggplot(data=df, aes(x=x, y=y)) + geom_point() + theme_bw() +        opts(panel.border = theme_border(c('b','l')) ) } # }

title: PEcAn worldmap — vwReg
text: Visually weighted regression / Watercolor plots

title: PEcAn worldmap — vwReg
code: vwReg(   formula,   data,   title = "",   B = 1000,   shade = TRUE,   shade.alpha = 0.1,   spag = FALSE,   spag.color = "darkblue",   mweight = TRUE,   show.lm = FALSE,   show.median = TRUE,   median.col = "white",   shape = 21,   show.CI = FALSE,   method = stats::loess,   bw = FALSE,   slices = 200,   palette = (grDevices::colorRampPalette(c("#FFEDA0", "#DD0000"), bias = 2))(20),   ylim = NULL,   quantize = "continuous",   add = FALSE,   ... )

title: PEcAn worldmap — vwReg
text: formula variables plot. See examples data data frame containing variables used formula title passed ggplot B = number bootstrapped smoothers shade plot shaded confidence region? shade.alpha CI shading fade edges? (reducing alpha; 0 = alpha decrease, 0.1 = medium alpha decrease, 0.5 = strong alpha decrease) spag plot spaghetti lines? spag.color color spaghetti lines mweight median smoother visually weighted? show.lm linear regression line plotted? show.median median smoother plotted? median.col color median smoother shape shape points show.CI 95% CI limits plotted? method fitting function spaghettis; default: loess bw = TRUE: define default b&w-palette slices number slices x y direction shaded region. Higher numbers make smoother plot, takes longer draw. go beyond 500 palette provide custom color palette watercolors ylim restrict range watercoloring quantize either 'continuous', 'SD'. latter case, get three color regions 1, 2, 3 SD (idea John Mashey) add add == FALSE, new ggplot returned. add == TRUE, elements returned, can added existing ggplot ('+' operator) ... parameters passed fitting function, case loess, example, 'span = .9', 'family = 'symmetric”

title: PEcAn worldmap — vwReg
text: NULL plot side effect

title: PEcAn worldmap — vwReg
